185667840.review:
I was looking forward to this game more than the previous two. Lightning is an awesome character, but unfortunately this game has many issues that luckily newer titles have fixed. 

Time. This is an issue for obvious reasons, but what makes the time concept worse is the way the game is designed. Example, I need four digits for a code to get through to a meeting. I am told the meeting occurs at night and I need to have the code before then. One piece of the code is locked behind a gate  that doesn't open until midnight. Crap design.

Quests in general are super disappointing because there are ZERO quest markers. Absolutely dumb a game focused on doing as many quests as possible to get stronger doesn't think to add quest markers. One quest tells me to look at "north station" for the item. I found the item. Nowhere near north station. Big fail on the devs. 

Many quests are time-gated and the NPCs that give them move around depending on the time. This can vary when you are picking up the quest for the first time, or turning the quest in. The game gives you no information as to where tf these quests are. You are constantly draining your time wandering around aimlessly while Hope will not stfu. 

I know this game came out in a time where SE was in a bad period. I am glad they add quest markers and navigation now on all newer titles. Absolutely ridiculous that I have to depend on Google and YouTube because your developers are too lazy to add basic features into the game. 

The game has good elements and the overall clock isn't terrible, but the time gated quests combined with no markers just makes this game a huge chore to play. Rebirth, Remake, FF 15 AND 16 all mark quests and sold much better than this game. Play those games and hope they remake these games with action combat and quest markers. It's nice and relaxing playing newer FF titles and having just about all the quest information IN THE GAME. Not having a guide pulled up on another monitor for everything.

The combat system in this game is more tolerable than the previous two, but it's still not great. You can actually block based on timing now, which is good but you can barely move around. Your skills are tied to that dumb ATB meter and you change clothes to do different attacks. It's like the game is trying to do action combat but it just can't. 

I would love to see the entire 13 trilogy remade using modern action combat and big interesting worlds. The trilogy would be so amazing but they all suffer from little to do, extremely hard difficulty spikes, and horrible combat systems.

184421073.review:
[h1] Final Fantasy XIII : Lightning Returns – Quand la fin du monde rime avec la mode et le chaos [/h1]
[i] Ou comment Square Enix a décidé de mélanger apocalypses, garde-robes et gameplay sous stéroïdes 🌀✨ [/i]

[hr][/hr]

[h2] [b] La première impression : « Tu es la Sauveuse. Non, pas toi, Lightning. Toi, le joueur. » [/b] [/h2]

Dès que tu lances Lightning Returns, le jeu te hurle que tu as 13 jours pour sauver le monde. Oui, rien que ça. Pas de pression. Ajoute à ça un compte à rebours omniprésent, une carte qui semble avoir été dessinée par un stagiaire fatigué, et un gameplay complètement remanié, et tu te retrouves à penser : « Ok, je vais souffrir… mais avec style. »

Si tu pensais que Final Fantasy XIII et XIII-2 étaient complexes, attends de plonger dans cet univers où chaque seconde compte, chaque choix est crucial, et chaque tenue débloque des super-pouvoirs. Oui, des tenues. Parce qu’être la Sauveuse n’empêche pas d’être à la pointe de la mode. 👗⚔️

[hr][/hr]

[h2] [b] Les + : La fin du monde, mais fabuleuse [/b] [/h2]

[b] 1) Une Lightning plus badass que jamais 💪⚡ : [/b]
Lightning n’est plus seulement une héroïne. Elle est une Sauveuse divine, une guerrière solitaire qui jongle entre combats intenses et gestion du temps. Sa personnalité froide et déterminée brille encore plus ici, même si parfois, tu te demandes si elle ne ferait pas mieux de sourire un peu. Mais bon, sauver le monde, c’est stressant, non ?

[b] 2) Un système de combat dynamique et addictif 🎮🔥 : [/b]
Adieu les combats à trois personnages des précédents opus, ici, c’est Lightning contre le monde entier. Tu passes d’une tenue (pardon, schema) à l’autre en temps réel, en mixant attaques physiques, magies, et esquives. C’est nerveux, c’est stratégique, et c’est tellement fun que tu oublies presque le stress du compte à rebours.

[b] 3) Une garde-robe digne d’un défilé post-apocalyptique 👗🌟 : [/b]
Le jeu te donne des dizaines de tenues à débloquer, et chacune modifie ton style de combat. Besoin de plus de force brute ? Enfile une armure imposante. Envie d’être rapide comme l’éclair (jeu de mots 100 % assumé) ? Opte pour une tenue légère. Et si tu veux juste être classe ? Il y a une tenue pour ça aussi.

[b] 4) Un monde vivant et un calendrier stressant 🕒🌍 : [/b]
Chaque région du jeu suit un cycle jour/nuit, avec des quêtes, des événements et des ennemis qui changent en fonction de l’heure. C’est immersif, mais ça te donne aussi ce sentiment constant de courir contre la montre. Spoiler : tu vas courir. Beaucoup.

[b] 5) La fin d’une trilogie épique 🌌⚔️ : [/b]
Lightning Returns conclut la saga Final Fantasy XIII de manière ambitieuse. L’histoire est un peu bizarre (ok, très bizarre), mais elle boucle la boucle avec style. Si tu as suivi les deux premiers opus, tu te sentiras récompensé… et un peu perdu...

[hr][/hr]

[h2] [b] Les - : Quand le chaos devient un peu trop chaotique 😵🔄 [/b] [/h2]

[b] 1) Un compte à rebours omniprésent… et oppressant 🕑⚡ : [/b]
Le concept des 13 jours est génial en théorie, mais en pratique, il te met une pression constante. Tu veux explorer ? Résoudre des quêtes secondaires ? Eh bien, dépêche-toi, parce que l’horloge ne s’arrête jamais. Même pas pour souffler.

[b] 2) Une carte qui te perd plus qu’elle ne t’aide 🗺️❓ : [/b]
Naviguer dans les différentes régions du jeu peut être un casse-tête. Les chemins ne sont pas toujours clairs, et les indications manquent parfois de précision. Résultat ? Tu passes plus de temps à chercher où aller qu’à sauver le monde.

[b] 3) Une histoire aussi dense que nébuleuse 📖🌫️ : [/b]
Si tu pensais que les intrigues de Final Fantasy XIII étaient complexes, prépare-toi à un niveau supérieur. Entre dieux, cycles de destruction, et quêtes secondaires parfois absurdes, tu vas souvent te demander : « Mais pourquoi je fais ça, déjà ? »

[b] 4) Des quêtes secondaires qui oscillent entre géniales et inutiles 🗡️🙄 : [/b]
Certaines quêtes sont mémorables et touchantes, tandis que d’autres te demandent de ramasser des objets ou de parler à des PNJ sans grand intérêt. Le contraste est frappant, et tu te surprends parfois à ignorer les quêtes secondaires pour éviter de perdre du temps.

[b] 5) Une bande-son moins marquante 🎶😕 : [/b]
La musique est bonne, mais elle ne reste pas autant en tête que les compositions iconiques des précédents Final Fantasy. Quelques morceaux brillent, mais beaucoup d’autres passent inaperçus.

[hr][/hr]

[h2] [b] Bilan : Une conclusion chaotique, mais inoubliable 🌌⚔️ [/b] [/h2]

Lightning Returns est une expérience unique qui mélange des idées brillantes et des choix audacieux. C’est nerveux, c’est beau, et c’est stressant. Si tu peux survivre au compte à rebours et à l’intrigue un peu foutraque, tu découvriras un jeu qui, malgré ses défauts, offre une conclusion satisfaisante à l’épopée de Lightning.

[b] En résumé : Si tu veux sauver le monde tout en changeant de tenue toutes les cinq minutes, ce jeu est fait pour toi. Prépare-toi à combattre, à courir, et à te demander pourquoi Lightning a plus de costumes qu’un défilé de mode. Vive la Sauveuse, et vive les vêtements magiques ! ⚡👗🗡️ [/b]

183918603.review:
A fairly solid game that takes itself a bit more seriously than XIII-2 and is better for it.

Centuries into the apocalypse, the world has grown used to its new situation. Nobody ages, and babies haven't been born in 500 years. With the only other option being death, the surviving population has solidified their lives into their own static personal narratives, regardless of how much misery those narratives bring them. Lightning's job, ordained by God, is to play the role of savior. By helping people break free of these self-imposed narratives you can save their souls and grant them passage to the new world as it is remade.

It's a compelling enough premise, though the game perhaps fails to use it as well as it could. The mechanics of saving souls are what you'd expect: typical video game quests, although the writing is sometimes interesting. Giving it a bit more gravitas is the time mechanic: you have 6 days (to start with, expandable up to 13 by main quests and 14 by side quests) to accomplish these tasks, and time ticks down whenever you're running around in the world. Do you have time to save this soul? Or should you leave it and focus on other, more valuble souls? Who is deserving of saving? Who is allowed to be saved? This theme echoes across some of the main quests as well, especially with regard to the Church who is nominally on your side.

The time mechanic is probably the most interesting part of the game, but you'll rarely find people who like it. Each in-game day translates to an hour IRL, with time frozen during menus, combat, and cutscenes. It's frightening at first, as running out of time means having to restart the game (albeit with your abilities, items, and stats retained), and many players have made mistakes that force them to retry several times. To help you with this, the game provides you with the Chronostasis ability, which freezes the clock for a minute or so. By fighting monsters frequently you can effectively run Chronostasis with near 100% uptime, giving you real-time hours of play out of a few minutes of the game clock, and effectively trivializing the time mechanic. On my first playthrough I had completed nearly every main and side quest by day 7 or so, and spent the next week frittering away time by sleeping at inns. The mechanic as a whole is either punishingly difficult or basically nothing, and neither are very enjoyable to experience.

The combat in the game is an interesting riff on the Command Synergy Battle system used in XIII and XIII-2, adapted to suit a more action-focused playstyle and to work with only a single party member. Combat still revolves around building stagger, but you'll also be interspersing timed guards and attacks while managing three different recharging ATB bars. While it doesn't really feel like the CSB system that preceded it, it's quite fun in its own right.

While the game does take itself a bit more seriously than XIII-2, it's still got a lot of the sillier worldbuilding concepts that game introduced, and consequently it feels even more divorced from XIII tonally. Characters from older games like Cid Raines will appear briefly in baffling ways and the game's attempt to put a capstone on the trilogy feels weak and impotent even when it does an okay job of being a sequel to XIII-2.

Oh, and you get to dress Lightning up! It's fun! Changing Serah's outfits in XIII-2 was one of my favorite things even if it was basically nothing, and here you have many more options to style Lightning up. Unfortunately, the way stats and abilities are tied to garbs means that you'll likely gravitate to a few outfits for combat purposes, but it's still fun regardless. Might've been nice to have had some sort of transmog or glamour system tho.

Technically the game doesn't perform great by modern standards, but the stuttering that made XIII-2 near unplayable is fixed. FPS is a bit low but not enough to significantly impact my experience. I didn't need any mods to get acceptable performance.

Recommend if you liked XIII-2 or action games, though I might wait for a sale.
